@RogerBorras someone is working on this now.

Overall, it looks great. Several comments:

1. The handling of init states is much better than the previous ad hoc way. However, I guess the user needs to re-construct the symbol, instead of just loading from json, in order to do inference, because the init states will be feeded inputs, instead of mx.zeros. Is there some way to make this easier?

2. The current interface handle time steps as a list, by using `SliceChannel` to split and later on re-merge. I'm wondering if there is a performance issue here (e.g. for applications with ~2k sequence length). Would it be better to use a fully packed tensor, and making one of the dimension as the time? (i.e. time-major / batch-major data layout). The benefit is also that cuDNN cell uses this layout, so it might be easier to wrap. Another benefit is that symbolically, an RNN with seq-len 10 and seq-len 20 will be exactly the same, except binded with different input shapes.

3. Currently there seem to be simple one layer RNN cell and then sequential RNN cell that could contain a stack of RNN cells. I'm wondering do we need to expose many different concepts to the user. With commonly used wrappers, for both the [tensorflow interface](https://keras.io/layers/recurrent/) and the [theano interface](https://lasagne.readthedocs.io/en/latest/modules/layers/recurrent.html), the RNN cell is a single function that could be used to create multiple layers with a single call. Plus, it can be mixed with other operators, without needing to explicitly call unroll. Our own [cuDNN RNN Cell demo](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rnn-time-major/rnn_cell_demo.py#L101) is an example that I think is kind of keeping the syntax as close as calling other mxnet operator.
I feel the DType to be okay since we will cast them to int using floor and ceil. Also, the for loops can not be removed.
It actually depends on the type ur using before casting to int. if the size of feature nao is small, it's ok. But for larger ones, you might overflow.

I agree it would be better to avoid Option in the public API whenever possible. However, better have Option than null.
We should get rid of the null.

@jyotilakra92 @starimpact There is one way to eliminate the for-loop. We can consider using `atomicAdd` to accumulate the output gradient to the chosen indices. Like to use ```atomicAdd(&g[chosen_ind], out_grad[ind])```. This will accelerate the speed of the backward computation.

Ah, sorry we have been super busy getting ready for a release. I haven't had time to investigate, but I am now curious about the outcome -- did the idea make it in somewhere else, or is it abandoned now? 

Again, my apologies for not responding initially.

@piiswrong I'm very sorry, we were hard at work getting ready for a freeze and I lost track of this thread. I see that #4586 is now closed, but aside from that, was the idea that the random source could be given partial size information using '0' for "don't know", and then that 0 would be resolved with backward inference later? I don't see how that would overcome the problem I described in which backward shape inference cannot in principle go through certain operators (e.g. Resize) that are on the DAG between the place where batch information is available (the layer output the sequences on which you want to apply variational dropout for example) to where the batch information is needed (the random source).

For the record the way that we ended up solving this is to have a 'useless' arg node, of dimensions (batch, n1, n2, ...) that we control and initialize to all zeros to which we add the random source. The resizer code knows about this arg node and can change its initial dimension size and have the rest of the graph infer in forward-mode correctly, with just one step of backward inference that reaches the random source. Slightly wasteful but completely reliable.

I'll try with master and let you know.
Are there any recent commits that affect memory allocation? Quickly skimming through the commits I couldn't see any.

Your learning task is non-trivial due to the extreme skew of y (many values around 0, few large), so it seems that using default optimizer resulted in some local optimum far away from the true optimium. Furthermore, 100 hidden nodes are quite a lot (low signal to noise ratio). 

Your example in R coding style could look as follows
```
library(mxnet)

# training set of 1000 samples
set.seed(8756)
x <- matrix(runif(3000), 1000, 3)
y <- x[, 1] * x[, 2] * x[, 3]

# validation set 
x2 <- matrix(runif(3000), 1000, 3)
y2 <- x2[, 1] * x2[, 2] * x2[, 3] 

# model
mx.set.seed(1)
fit <- mx.mlp(data = x, 
              label = y,
              hidden_node = 100,
              out_node = 1, 
              out_activation = "rmse", 
              learning.rate = 0.01,
              eval.metric = mx.metric.rmse,
              num.round = 350,
              array.batch.size = 30,
              optimizer = "adam")
sqrt(mean(predict(fit, x2) - y2)^2) # 0.0018

plot(y2 ~ t(predict(fit, x2)))
abline(0, 1)
```

but if I use 0.7 version mxnet, the speed ramains the same and faster than above:

1. Why would the init state be non zero for inference? @pluskid 
2. The current interface allows more flexibility. You can easily unroll it with rnn_unroll. Cudnn rnn will be called FusedRNN. I haven't decided if it should be a Cell or a function. Function is probably more natural in this case.
3. This can be a higher level interface.

Hi, @piiswrong, previously I have seen "cuDNN RNN Cell parameter initialization"  #3573 and your alternative solution #4644. #4644 doesn't conflict with this PR and cannot substitute this one. 

This PR revised Xavier implementation, which can bee seen as 'fault-tolerant' for any NDArray shape. For one dimension shape (such as cuDNN parameters), the key is using sqrt to 'mimic' two dimension shape, which has been verified as an effective method by test.

#4644 proposes an initializer registeration mechanism to adapt with various situations, which is compatible with RNNXavier that I introduced in rnn_cell_demo.py. But #4644 itself cannot resolve the 'LSTM_bias' defect. 

I think you can accept this PR firstly, then merge #4644, after that I can revise rnn_cell_demo.py again to use your registeration mechanism (of course, as a custom initializer in user side, it also may not need to register).

Besides, bucket_io.py revised to be compatible with python 3.x. Otherwise the program exit abnormally.
link to #4795 for later observation
updated to latest 0.9.3 mxnet, the problem solved.

Hello, I think you should actually be able to do it by using the get.output: 

```
resnet101<- mx.model.load("Models/Resnet101/resnet-101", iteration=0)

symbol<- resnet101$symbol
internals<- symbol$get.internals()
outputs<- internals$outputs

flatten<- internal2$get.output(which(outputs=="flatten0_output"))
```

Tricky part is that get.output seems to only accept a numeric index and not a named one. 

After, it should be relatively straightforward through the use of the initializers:  

```
new_fc<- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=flatten, num_hidden=24, name="new_fc_24") 
new_soft = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=new_fc, name='new_softmax')

arg_params_ori<- resnet101$arg.params
fc1_weights_ori<- arg_params_ori[["fc1_weight"]]

devices<- mx.ctx.default()
arg_params_new<- mxnet:::mx.model.init.params(symbol = new_soft, input.shape = c(224,224,3,32), initializer = mxnet:::mx.init.uniform(0.1), ctx = devices)$arg.params
fc1_weights_new<- arg_params_new[["new_fc_24_weight"]]

### Alternative
arg_params_new2<- mx.init.create(initializer = mx.init.uniform(0.1), shape.array = mx.symbol.infer.shape(new_soft, data=c(224,224,3,32))$arg.shapes, ctx = devices)
fc1_weights_new2<- arg_params_new2[["new_fc_24_weight"]]
```

And finally reassigning the original weights to the new initialiser for all but the new FC layer: 

```
arg_params_new_patch<- arg_params_new
arg_params_new_patch[setdiff(names(arg_params_new_patch), "new_fc_24_weight")]<- arg_params_ori[setdiff(names(arg_params_new_patch), "new_fc_24_weight")]
```

Thank you for the response.

Is it possible to replace the line `new_args = dict({k:arg_params[k] for k in arg_params if 'fc1' not in k})` in Python with something like `model$arg.params[c("fc1_weight", "fc1_bias")] <- NULL` in R? Or we should always use initializers?

@pluskid That's very hard given cudnn rnn packs weight.

I agree with Eric for the cuDNN part. It's really difficult to handle the weights when there are more than one layers. Also, is it possible to detect RNN-like patterns in the constructed symbol and use cuDNN-RNN as a kind of kernel fusion?

We traced it back to the fact that VOC has 1-based bounding box offsets leading to:

```
            # Make pixel indexes 0-based
            x1 = float(bbox.find('xmin').text) - 1
            y1 = float(bbox.find('ymin').text) - 1
            x2 = float(bbox.find('xmax').text) - 1
            y2 = float(bbox.find('ymax').text) - 1
```

subtracting 1 from an unsigned int whenever x1 or y1 is zero. After fixing our conversion script to user 1-based bounding box offsets, things are working.

Thank you rubber-ducky :)
